Short English Translation: Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjaya, after assembling in the holy land of Kurukshetra and desiring to fight, what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do?
Sanjaya said: On observing the Pandava army arranged in military formation, King Duryodhana approached his teacher Dronacharya and spoke these words.
Behold, O teacher, this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada, your wise disciple.
Here in this army are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhima and Arjuna: Yuyudhana, Virata, and Drupada, the maharatha.
There are also great, heroic, powerful fighters like Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the king of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Shaibya, the best of men.
The strong Yudhamanyu and the brave Uttamauja, the son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi—all great chariot-warriors.
O best of Brahmins, hear also about the principal generals on our side, who are especially qualified to lead. These I now recount unto you.
There are personalities like yourself, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, Ashwatthama, Vikarna, and Bhurishrava, who are ever victorious in battle.
And many other heroes who are determined to give up their lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled in battle.
Our strength is immeasurable, and we are perfectly protected by Grandfather Bhishma, whereas the strength of the Pandavas, carefully protected by Bhima, is limited.
Therefore, all of you stationed in your respective positions on all sides, protect Grandfather Bhishma alone.
Then Bhishma, the great valiant grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, blew his conch very loudly like the roar of a lion, giving joy to Duryodhana.
After that, conches, kettledrums, tabors, trumpets, and horns were all suddenly sounded, and the combined sound was tumultuous.
On the other side, both Krishna and Arjuna, stationed on a grand chariot drawn by white horses, sounded their transcendental conches.
Krishna blew His conch named Panchajanya; Arjuna blew his, the Devadatta; and Bhima, the voracious eater and performer of heroic tasks, blew the Paundra conch.
King Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew the Anantavijaya conch; Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and Manipushpaka conches.
The great archer King of Kashi, the great fighter Shikhandi, Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and the invincible Satyaki blew their conches.
Drupada, the sons of Draupadi, and the mighty-armed son of Subhadra also blew their conches, O King.
The sound resounding through the sky and the earth shattered the hearts of the sons of Dhritarashtra.
At that time, Arjuna, the son of Pandu, seated in the chariot bearing the banner of Hanuman, took up his bow and prepared to speak to Krishna.
Arjuna said: O Krishna, please place my chariot between the two armies.
So that I may see those assembled here, eager to fight, with whom I must engage in this great battle.
Let me look at those who have come here desiring to please the evil-minded Duryodhana.
Sanjaya said: Thus requested by Arjuna, Krishna placed the chariot between the two armies.
In front of Bhishma, Drona, and all the other kings, Krishna said: Behold, O Arjuna, all the Kurus assembled here.
Then Arjuna saw in both armies fathers, grandfathers, teachers, uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, and well-wishers.
Seeing all these relatives present, Arjuna, overwhelmed with compassion and despair, spoke the following.
Arjuna said: Seeing my own kinsmen gathered here, ready to fight, my limbs fail, my mouth dries up.
My body trembles, my hair stands on end, my bow slips from my hand, and my skin burns all over.
I am unable to stand here any longer. My mind is reeling, and I see only omens of misfortune, O Krishna!
I do not see any good in killing my kinsmen in battle, O Krishna. I desire no victory, kingdom, or pleasures.
What is the use of the kingdom, pleasures, or life itself if those for whom we desire them are present here to die in battle?
Teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives...
...for whose sake we desire gain, are here in battle, ready to give up their lives and wealth.
I do not wish to kill them, even if I am killed, not even for the sovereignty of the three worlds, what to speak of the earth!
Sin will overcome us if we kill such aggressors. Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra and our relatives.
How can we be happy by killing our own kinsmen, O Madhava?
Though they are driven by greed and see no wrong in destroying families, why should we, who see the sin, engage in this crime?
With the destruction of the family, the eternal family tradition is lost, and the rest of the family becomes irreligious.
When irreligion prevails, the women of the family become corrupt, and from such corruption, unwanted progeny are born.
By the rise of unwanted progeny, family traditions and duties are destroyed, and eternal dharma perishes.
Such a breach leads those who destroy family traditions to dwell perpetually in hell.
O Krishna, we have heard that those who destroy family traditions dwell always in hell.
Alas, we are engaged in committing a great sin, driven by greed, ready to kill our own kin.
It would be better if the sons of Dhritarashtra, armed, killed me unarmed and unresisting.
Sanjaya said: Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and sat down in his chariot, his mind overwhelmed with sorrow.
Arjuna’s will collapses completely, and he remains despondent in the middle of the battlefield.
Sanjaya said: Seeing Arjuna full of compassion and despair, with tearful eyes, Krishna spoke the following words.
Krishna said: From where has this dejection come upon you in this hour of crisis? It is not fitting for an Aryan.
O Arjuna, give up this petty weakness of heart. Rise, O scorcher of enemies!
Arjuna said: How can I fight against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of worship, O Krishna?
It is better to live by begging than to kill great souls.
We do not know which is better—conquering or being conquered.
I am confused about my duty. I ask You to tell me clearly what is best. I am Your disciple, surrendered to You.
I see no solution to this sorrow that is drying up my senses.
Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus, Arjuna remained silent and sat with a heavy heart.
Krishna, with a gentle smile, began to speak profound words to the despondent Arjuna.
You grieve for those who should not be grieved for, yet speak words of wisdom. The wise do not mourn the living or the dead.
Never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings—nor will any of us cease to exist in the future.
Just as childhood, youth, and old age happen to the body, so does the passing to another body. The wise are not deluded by this.
Pleasure and pain, heat and cold arise from sense perception. They come and go—endure them, O Arjuna.
That person who remains undisturbed in pleasure and pain is fit for immortality.
The unreal has no existence; the real never ceases to be. Truth is discerned by seers.
That by which all is pervaded is indestructible. No one can destroy the imperishable soul.
Bodies are perishable; the indwelling Self is eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable.
He who thinks the soul kills or is killed is ignorant. The soul neither kills nor is killed.
The soul is never born, never dies, nor ceases to exist. It is unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient.
One who knows this eternal soul as indestructible cannot kill nor cause killing.
As a person discards worn-out clothes, so the soul discards old bodies and takes new ones.
Weapons cannot cut it, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, wind cannot dry it.
This soul is unbreakable, incombustible, insoluble, and constant.
It is said to be invisible, inconceivable, and immutable. Knowing this, you should not grieve.
Even if you think the soul is born and dies, still you should not grieve.
Death is certain for the born and birth for the dead. So you should not lament over the inevitable.
All beings are unmanifest before birth, manifest between birth and death, and unmanifest again. Why lament?
Some see the soul as amazing, others speak of it as amazing, and others even after hearing do not understand it.
The soul residing in the body can never be slain. Therefore, you should not grieve for any creature.
Considering your dharma as a warrior, you should not waver. For a warrior, nothing is better than a righteous battle.
Fortunate are the warriors who gain such an opportunity for righteous war, opening the gates of heaven.
But if you do not engage in this righteous war, then abandoning your dharma and honor, you shall incur sin.
People will speak of your infamy forever. For a man of honor, dishonor is worse than death.
Great generals will think you fled the battlefield out of fear. You will lose your reputation.
Your enemies will mock your ability. What can be more painful than that?
If you are killed, you will attain heaven; if you win, you enjoy the earth. Therefore, rise and fight.
Treat pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat alike, and engage in battle. Then you will not incur sin.
This knowledge has been taught to you from the Sankhya perspective. Now hear it from the standpoint of Karma Yoga.
In this path, no effort is ever wasted, and there is no failure. Even a little progress protects from great fear.
Those with resolute intellect have single-pointed focus. The minds of the irresolute are many-branched.
The unwise delight in the flowery words of the Vedas, saying there is nothing else.
Attached to pleasure and power, their minds are not led to true concentration.
Those whose minds are attracted to enjoyment and power cannot possess the steady intellect of the meditative.
The Vedas deal with the three gunas. Rise above them, O Arjuna. Be established in the Self, beyond gain and protection.
All the purposes of a well can be served by a vast lake. Similarly, one who knows the Absolute transcends Vedic ritual.
You have the right to work, but not to the fruits. Never be attached to results.
Perform your duty with equanimity, abandoning attachment. Success and failure are equal. This is Yoga.
Action is far inferior to Buddhi Yoga (wisdom in action). Take refuge in wisdom.
One who is devoted to Buddhi Yoga casts off both good and bad actions.
The wise, united with Buddhi Yoga, abandon the fruits of action and attain eternal peace.
When your intellect crosses beyond delusion, you shall be indifferent to heard and unheard teachings.
When your intellect, confused by the Vedas, becomes steady in Self-realization, then you shall attain Yoga.
Arjuna asks: What is the description of a self-realized person? How does such a person speak, sit, walk?
Krishna replies: When one gives up desires, satisfied in the Self alone, one is called steadfast in wisdom.
One who is not disturbed by pain or pleasure and is free from attachment, fear, and anger is truly wise.
One who is unattached in all situations and neither rejoices nor hates when good or bad occurs is firmly established in wisdom.
Like a tortoise withdrawing its limbs, a wise person withdraws senses from sense objects.
The objects may cease for the abstainer, but taste remains. Even that disappears upon Self-realization.
The turbulent senses forcibly carry away even the mind of a wise person striving for perfection.
Restraining all senses, the wise should sit focused on Me. One whose senses are under control is steadfast.
While contemplating objects, attachment arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.
From anger comes delusion; from delusion, memory loss; from memory loss, intellect is destroyed; from loss of intellect, ruin follows.
But one who moves among objects with senses under control, free from attachment and aversion, attains peace.
In that peace, all sorrows are destroyed. The intellect of the peaceful soon becomes steady.
Without steady intellect, there is no contemplation; without contemplation, no peace; and without peace, how can there be happiness?
When the mind follows the wandering senses, it carries away the intellect like the wind carries a boat on water.
Therefore, O mighty-armed, one whose senses are completely restrained has steady wisdom.
What is night to others is day to the disciplined; what is day to others is night to the sage.
Like an ocean unmoved by rivers, one who is unmoved by desires attains peace.
One who abandons desires and ego, and acts without possessiveness, attains peace.
This is the Brahmic state. Established in it, one is never deluded and attains oneness with Brahman at death.
